title: CBC Life
text:
Nothing beats homemade bread on the dinner table. These breadsticks are great with soups and salads, your family’s favourite lasagne, and even as an after-school snack. Let the kids help shape and roll out the dough and choose their own toppings. Any kind of spice, seed and salt will be delicious.

Breadsticks

Note: If using a stand mixer, simply follow the directions using a dough hook attachment and knead on medium speed until smooth and elastic, about 8 to 10 minutes.

Ingredients

Bread dough:

1 cup warm whole milk

1 package (8 g) active dry yeast

1 tbsp granulated sugar

¼ cup olive oil

2 ½ cups (350 g) flour

1 tbsp Italian seasoning

1 tsp kosher salt

½ tsp garlic powder

Topping:

4 tsp sesame seeds

1 tsp garlic powder

½ tsp kosher salt

2 tbsp olive oil

Preparation

Line two baking sheets with parchment and set aside.

Gently stir together the milk, yeast and sugar in a small bowl and set aside until frothy, about 10 minutes.

Whisk together the flour, Italian seasoning, salt and garlic powder in a large bowl.

Stir the olive oil into the yeast mixture. Pour into the flour mixture. Mix all of the ingredients together to form a ragged dough.

Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth and elastic, adding up to an extra two tablespoons of flour, if needed, for about 8 to 10 minutes.

Transfer the dough to a well-oiled bowl and cover with plastic wrap or a damp tea towel. Let it rise in a warm area until doubled in size, about 1 hour.

For the topping, mix together the sesame seeds, garlic powder and salt in a small bowl.

Heat the oven to 375F degrees.

Punch the excess air out of the risen dough then transfer the dough onto a lightly-floured surface and divide in half. Roll each piece into a 9x13-inch rectangle. Brush both rectangles with olive oil and sprinkle with topping. Cut each piece into 24 nine-inch strips.

Transfer strips onto prepared baking sheets and bake until golden and crisp, 14-18 minutes.

Yield: Makes 48 breadsticks
description: Judge Bruno Feldeisen demonstrates how to master this kid-friendly bake from scratch.
